title: Yuet-Keung Lo is Associate Professor of Chinese Studies at the National University of Singapore. He specializes in Chinese intellectual history covering Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism and their interactions from the classical period to late imperial times. He has published one book and numerous articles in these areas, and his recent publications include “The Drama of Numskulls: Structure, Texture, and Functions of the Scripture of One Hundred Parables
Conversion to Chastity: A Buddhist Catalyst in Early Imperial China
Change beyond Syncretism: Ouyi Zhixu’s Buddhist Hermeneutics of the Yijing
, and “From a Dual Soul to a Unitary Soul: The Babel of Soul Terminologies in Early China

title: Mu-Chou Poo received his PhD in Egyptology from the Johns Hopkins University in 1984, and is currently Research Fellow at the Institute of History and Philology, Academia Sinica, Taipei. His research interests encompass early and medieval China and ancient Egypt and he publishes in Chinese and English. His books in English include Wine and Wine Offering in the Religion of Ancient Egypt
